text.p:
Biexciton (bound two-exciton state) and scattering two-exciton states play an essential role in optical
nonlinearity of semiconducting material. In general, it is difficult to calculate these two-exciton states because of
a four-body problem consisting of two electrons and two holes. However, two-exciton states consisting of
Frenkel excitons can be described by a simple tight-binding model with a nearest-neighbor approximation. The
model Hamiltonian has been extensively studied. Analytical expression of a biexciton for one-dimensional (1D)
chain [1] and the third-order nonlinear susceptibility of finite 1D chain [2] have been obtained from this model
Hamiltonian. The former is limited to the biexciton, and the latter calculates the susceptibility without obtaining
wave functions of two-exciton states. For studying nonlinear optical processes in a microcavity, however, the
wave functions are necessary in order to calculate transition rates from an exciton to two-exciton state via a
cavity photon [3,4].

In this paper, I provide a rapid calculation method for calculating energies and wave functions of the
two exciton-states in the tight-binding Hamiltonian. The method has been reported in the case of a 1D chain [5].
I extend this method to 2D and 3D systems. Since the two-exciton states are obtained from a bisection method,
the present method needs much less memory capacity and computation time than the matrix diagonalization.

The two-exciton energies are determined from two kinds of functions U(E) and W(E), each of which
has singular points. Figure 1 shows U(E) and two-exciton energies for 41x41x41 sites of 3D lattice by applying
CuCl parameters. A horizontal dotted line represents 1/δ, where δ denotes two-exciton interaction between
nearest-neighbor sites. The two-exciton energies are obtained as the crossing points between the horizontal
dotted line and the function U(E) indicated by solid curves. The two-exciton energies can be definitely obtained
by using a bisection method because all singular points of U(E) can be obtained. Inset shows U(E) around the
biexciton energy. The two-exciton energies obtained from a function W(E) are marked by closed inverted
triangles. These two-exciton energies agree with those calculated from diagonalization indicated by open circles.
Figure 2 shows wave function in wave-vector space of a biexciton state for CuCl parameters.
Small lattice size 21x21x21 is chosen because of clearness to see. The size of spheres denotes the amplitude of
the wave function.

The present method is useful for analysis of experimental data because the parameter δ of the two-
exciton interaction can be immediately determined from an observed binding energy of biexciton.
